title: Victor Moses with bicycle
creator: Harriet's Photograph Collection, 1868-1996 (P HC)7
description: A man stands holding a bicycle with thin tires and curved handlebars. He has a mustache and wears a dark jacket, buttoned shirt, and trousers. His stance is straight and confident, and the bike rests lightly beside him, showing both hands on the handlebars in a simple studio-like setting.
subject: Man; Safety Bicycle; Portrait; Inside
source:
Oregon Digital
Unique Cultural Heritage Collection

citation: OSU Special Collections & Archives Research Center, Oregon State University. (28 Oct 2025). Victor Moses with bicycle Retrieved from https://oregondigital.org/concern/images/df70cv56z

title: Transportation to Fair - Woman on bicycle
creator: New York World's Fair (1939-1940 : New York, N.Y.)
description: A woman stands smiling beside her bicycle on a paved street. She wears a short sleeve blouse, a knee length skirt, and flat shoes. The bike has a basket on the front and a bag on the back. Behind her are flags, trees, and a large rounded building with tall windows.
subject: Woman; Safety Bicycle; Portrait; Outside; Leisure
source: New York Public Libraries, Digital Collections
image_alt_text: A woman stands smiling beside her bicycle on a paved street. She wears a short sleeve blouse, a knee length skirt, and flat shoes. The bike has a basket on the front and a bag on the back. Behind her are flags, trees, and a large rounded building with tall windows.
citation: Manuscripts and Archives Division, The New York Public Library. "Transportation to Fair - Woman on bicycle" The New York Public Library Digital Collections. 1935 - 1945. https://digitalcollections.nypl.org/items/37dd1300-c54f-012f-9b7e-58d385a7bc34

title: Sports - Bicycling - Man on bicycle
creator: New York World's Fair (1939-1940 : New York, N.Y.)
description: A man rides a bicycle at night wearing a long-sleeve athletic shirt that says “New York” and matching pants. He looks focused ahead as he pedals, and the dark background makes him and the bike stand out under the light.
subject: Man; Safety Bicycle; Portrait; Outside
source: New York Public Libraries, Digital Collections

title: Group of Riders at Cycle Trades Field Day in Portland, Oregon
creator: Brown, Joseph Stephen, 1889-1960
description: This photo shows a group of young boys lined up with their bicycles, getting ready for what looks like a race or a group ride. They’re leaning forward on their bikes focused on something ahead of them. Most of them are wearing caps, button up shirts, and rolled up sleeves. In the background, you can see some tall trees, buildings, and people watching giving the scene a small town community feel. It looks like an outdoor event where kids gathered to take part in what could be a race.
subject: Man; Boy; Group; Outside; Leisure; Safety Bicycle
source: Oregon Historical Society. Library. (Digital Collections)
image_alt_text: This photo shows a group of young boys lined up with their bicycles, getting ready for what looks like a race or a group ride. It looks like an outdoor event where kids gathered to take part in what could be a race.
citation: Oregon Historical Society. "Group of Riders at Cycle Trades Field Day in Portland, Oregon." OHS Digital Collections, 1926, https://digitalcollections.ohs.org/orglot1003-f11-003.

title: Students with Bicycles
creator: Unknown
description: Five men are sitting together in a grassy field with two bicycles behind them. They seem relaxed, some leaning back while others hold books or papers. The group is dressed neatly in shirts, jackets, and hats, and the trees in the background suggest they stopped to rest during a ride or picnic
subject: Man; Group; Safety Bicycle; Outside; Leisure
source: University of Minnesota Libraries, University Archives.

citation: Students with Bicycles. 1894. University of Minnesota Libraries, University Archives., umedia.lib.umn.edu/item/p16022coll175:4654 Accessed 01 Nov 2025.

title: The new woman and her bicycle
creator: Opper, Fredrick Burr, 1857-1937
description: Full color cartoon spread. The central figure is a confidently posed woman in exaggerated, fashionable bloomer-style cycling attire. She stands tall with her hands in her pockets, wearing puffed sleeves, a fitted jacket, plaid knee-length bloomers, stockings, and heeled shoes. On the top left a older woman rides a bike, labeled as a “new” servant girl. The middle left A woman hauls laundry in a large basket mounted on her bicycle, labeled “The ‘new’ Washerwoman.” Two men stand beside a pile of leaves watching her. Bottom left A woman pedals a bicycle pulling a small carriage containing a baby holding a parasol, labeled “The ‘new’ Nurse-Girl.” Top center A framed portrait of a woman cycling is propped behind the centeral figure. Top right a woman rides ahead of. a man, who is on a tricycle carrying a bundle; it is labeled “The ‘new’ Suburban Lady, starting for a long ride.” Middle right young  women up ride in a line, one playing a bass drum, one holding a tambourine, the other reading as she cycles. Labeled as “The ‘new’ Society young Ladies.”Bottom right: A grieving widow dressed in mourning clothes rides to a cemetery. Off to the side is a bicycle leaning against a gravestone. Labeled “The ‘new’ Widow.”
subject: Group; Leisure; Safety Bicycle
source: Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division Washington, D.C. 20540 USA
rights: The Organization that has made the Item available reasonably believes that the Item is not restricted by copyright or related rights, but a conclusive determination could not be made. Labeled as “The ‘new’ Society young Ladies.”Bottom right: A grieving widow dressed in mourning clothes rides to a cemetery. Off to the side is a bicycle leaning against a gravestone. Labeled “The ‘new’ Widow.”
citation: Opper, Frederick Burr. The “New Woman” and Her Bicycle — There Will Be Several Varieties of Her. 19 June 1895, chromolithograph. Library of Congress, Prints & Photographs Division, https://www.loc.gov/pictures/item/2012648801/

title: Some popular conceptions that the wheeling mania will change
creator: Oppen, Fredrick Burr, 1857-1937
description:
This is a full-color, two-page satirical cartoon spread. The illustration is divided into several comic vignettes arranged around a large central scene. Each vignette depicts imagined consequences of the “wheel craze,”  and bright pastel colors. In the centeral illustration A large group of cyclists race across a rough, reddish landscape.
Around the riders there are hordes of “red devils” representing danger or mischief.
The riders struggle over rocks, turning the scene into a wild stampede.
subject: Group; Outside; Safety Bicycle
source: Library of congress prints and photographs division Washington, D.C. 20540
rights: The Organization that has made the Item available reasonably believes that the Item is not restricted by copyright or related rights, but a conclusive determination could not be made. Please refer to the organization that has made the Item available for more information. You are free to use this Item in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use.

citation: Opper, Freddrick B. Some popular conceptions that the wheeling mania will change / F. Opper. N.Y. : Published by Keppler & Schwarzmann, 1897 July 21, 1897.

title: Wheeling on Riverside Drive
creator: Harper & Bros., New York, New York, USA
description: A man and woman seated side by side ride a wide bicycle vehicle with two large wheels at either side and a small wheel at the front. The couple appears to be in conversation while riding along the Hudson River, which is visible at left. At right, behind the couple, a man rides a tall pennyfarthing bicycle. Further in the background, another couple rides a bicycle in yet a different style. In the background, at right, a coachman visible behind two horses.
subject: Group; Outside; Leisure; Man; Woman; Penny-Farthing
source: Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum Collection Drawings, Prints, and Graphic Design Department
image_alt_text: Historic photograph showing a group of people cycling on a road along Riverside Drive in a bustling city environment.
citation: “Man with Bicycle.” National Museum of American History, 2025, n2t.net/ark:/65665/ng49ca746b3-f6ad-704b-e053-15f76fa0b4fa. Accessed 13 Nov. 2025.

title: Ordinary Racing Bicycle, 1887
creator: Rudge, Daniel
description: Dan Rudge & Co., of Coventry, England manufactured this Ordinary racing bicycle around 1887. This racing model was undoubtedly sold by their U.S. agents, Stoddard, Lovering & Co., of Boston, Massachusetts. The bicycle was originally owned by Godfrey A. S. Wieners who used it in racing events held by the Manhattan Athletic Club.
subject: Man; Portrait; Inside; Leeisure; Penny-Farthing
source: National Museum of American History
image_alt_text: A detailed photo of a high-wheel racing bicycle from 1887, displayed in a historical collection.
citation: Wheeling, Print. “Print, Wheeling on Riverside Drive, 1886.” Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum, 2015, collection.cooperhewitt.org/view/objects/asitem/id/109024. Accessed 13 Nov. 2025.

title: George Cannady on decorated bicycle
creator: Cannady, Beatrice
description: Beatrice Morrow Cannady's son, George, sits on a bicycle decorated with roses that he rode in the 1921 Rose Festival Parade. He wears a white hat and costume with a ribbon pinned to the lapel. Cannady won the award for best decorated bicycle that year. Partially legible handwriting on the back of the photo reads, "393 Oak St" / "For stereopticon."
subject: Boy; Portrait; Outside; Leisure; Safety Bicycle
source: Oregon Historical Society. Library. (Digital Collections)
image_alt_text: Photo of a young boy riding a decorated bicycle. He is wearing a costume for a bicycle parade.
citation: Oregon Historical Society. "George Cannady on Decorated Bicycle." OHS Digital Collections, 1921, digitalcollections.ohs.org/coll702-f31-015.
